questions.clue: In 1876, Alexander Graham Bell was granted a patent for this communication device.
This American inventor is credited with inventing the phonograph in 1877.
The Wright brothers successfully flew the first powered aircraft in this North Carolina location in 1903.
In 1928, Sir Alexander Fleming discovered this antibiotic that revolutionized medicine.
This French chemist invented the first process for pasteurization in 1864, which bears his name.
This Italian dish traditionally consists of thinly sliced raw beef served with lemon, olive oil, and Parmesan cheese.
A staple of Japanese cuisine, this dish is made with vinegared rice and often includes seafood, vegetables, and nori.
Originating from Mexico, this dish is a type of stuffed corn dough, usually filled with meats, cheeses, or chilies and wrapped in corn husks.
This spicy and tangy soup from Thailand often features shrimp, lemongrass, lime juice, and chili peppers.
A national dish of Ethiopia, this platter is often served with injera and includes a variety of stews and curries known as 'wats'.
In 'The Taming of the Shrew,' this character is the older sister of Bianca.
In 'Twelfth Night,' this character is a steward to Olivia and is often the butt of jokes.
In 'The Winter's Tale,' this character is a shepherdess who falls in love with Prince Florizel.
In 'Measure for Measure,' this character is the deputy who enforces Vienna's strict morality laws.
In 'Cymbeline,' this character is the Queen's son and a brutish stepson to the King.
The closest star to Earth, this celestial body is the center of our solar system.
This term describes the force that keeps planets in orbit around stars.
These remnants of supernova explosions are known for their immense density and strong gravitational pull.
This theoretical boundary around a black hole is the point beyond which nothing can escape its gravitational pull.
This term refers to the apparent change in frequency of light from a source moving relative to an observer, often used to understand the movement of galaxies.
This artist created the famous marble statue of David completed in 1504.
Known for his bronze statue of David, this early Renaissance sculptor was a pioneer in the use of perspective.
This artist's equestrian statue of Gattamelata in Padua was one of the first major Renaissance sculptures to revive classical equestrian monuments.
Completed in the 1470s, this artist's work, 'The Gates of Paradise,' adorns the Baptistery of Florence.
This sculptor's works, including 'Perseus with the Head of Medusa,' marked a return to the classical ideals of harmony and beauty.

final.clue: This country, the world's largest archipelagic state, consists of more than 17,000 islands and is home to over 270 million people, making it the fourth most populous nation.
